member.name: T:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2
member.summary: Represents a collection of keys and values, where each element will expire and be automatically removed according to the properties "SlidingExpiration" and "AbsoluteExpiration"
member.typeparam: The type of the keys in the ExpiringDictionary.
The type of the values in the ExpiringDictionary
member.remarks: The ExpiringDictionary generic class provides a mapping from a set of keys to a set of values. Each addition to the ExpiringDictionary consists of a value and its associated key. Retrieving a value by using its key is very fast, close to O(1), because the ExpiringDictionary class is implemented with an internal Dictionary witch is implemented as a hash table. Note The speed of retrieval depends on the quality of the hashing algorithm of the type specified for TKey. As long as an object is used as a key in the ExpiringDictionary, it must not change in any way that affects its hash value. Every key in an ExpiringDictionary must be unique according to the ExpiringDictionary's equality comparer. A key cannot be a null reference, but a value can be, if the value type TValue is a reference type. ExpiringDictionary requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. You can specify an implementation of the IEqualityComparer generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter; if you do not specify an implementation, the default generic equality comparer EqualityComparer.Default is used. If type TKey implements the System.IEquatable generic interface, the default equality comparer uses that implementation. The capacity of an ExpiringDictionary is the number of elements the ExpiringDictionary can hold. In this implementation, the default initial capacity for an ExpiringDictionary is 3; however, that default might change in future versions of the .NET Framework. As elements are added to an ExpiringDictionary, the capacity is automatically increased as required by reallocating the internal array.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ExpiringDictionary class that is empty, has the default initial capacity, and uses the default equality comparer for the key type.
member.remarks: Every key in an ExpiringDictionary must be unique according to the default equality comparer. ExpiringDictionary requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. This constructor uses the default generic equality comparer, EqualityComparer.Default. If type TKey implements the System.IEquatable generic interface, the default equality comparer uses that implementation. Alternatively, you can specify an implementation of the IEqualityComparer generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter. This constructor is an O(1) operation.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ExpiringDictionary class that is empty, has the default initial capacity, and uses the default equality comparer for the key type, and uses a specific sliding expiration.
member.param: A TimeSpan indicating the period of sliding expiration
member.remarks: Every key in an ExpiringDictionary must be unique according to the default equality comparer. ExpiringDictionary requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. This constructor uses the default generic equality comparer, EqualityComparer.Default. If type TKey implements the System.IEquatable generic interface, the default equality comparer uses that implementation. Alternatively, you can specify an implementation of the IEqualityComparer generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter. This constructor is an O(1) operation.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ExpiringDictionary class that is empty, has the specified initial capacity, and uses the default equality comparer for the key type.
member.param: The initial number of elements that the ExpiringDictionary can contain.
member.exception: capacity is less than 0.
member.remarks: Every key in an ExpiringDictionary must be unique according to the default equality comparer. The capacity of an ExpiringDictionary is the number of elements that can be added to the ExpiringDictionary before resizing is necessary. As elements are added to an ExpiringDictionary, the capacity is automatically increased as required by reallocating the internal array. If the size of the collection can be estimated, specifying the initial capacity eliminates the need to perform a number of resizing operations while adding elements to the ExpiringDictionary. ExpiringDictionary requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. This constructor uses the default generic equality comparer, EqualityComparer.Default. If type TKey implements the System.IEquatable generic interface, the default equality comparer uses that implementation. Alternatively, you can specify an implementation of the IEqualityComparer generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter. This constructor is an O(1) operation.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.Add(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds the specified key and value to the ExpiringDictionary.
member.param: The key of the element to add.
The value of the element to add. The value can be a null reference
member.exception: key is a null reference
An element with the same key already exists in the ExpiringDictionary.
member.remarks: You can also use the Item property to add new elements by setting the value of a key that does not exist in the ExpiringDictionary; for example, myExpiringDictionary[myKey] = myValue. However, if the specified key already exists in the ExpiringDictionary, setting the Item property overwrites the old value. In contrast, the Add method throws an exception if a value with the specified key already exists. If the Count property value already equals the capacity, the capacity of the ExpiringDictionary is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array, and the existing elements are copied to the new array before the new element is added. A key cannot be a null reference, but a value can be, if TValue is a reference type. If Count is less than the capacity, this method approaches an O(1) operation. If the capacity must be increased to accommodate the new element, this method becomes an O(n) operation, where n is Count.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.Clear
member.summary: Removes all keys and values from the ExpiringDictionary.
member.remarks: The Count property is set to 0, and references to other objects from elements of the collection are also released. The capacity remains unchanged. This method is an O(n) operation, where n is Count.

member.summary: Determines whether the ExpiringDictionary contains the specified key.
member.param: The key to locate in the ExpiringDictionary.
member.returns: true if the ExpiringDictionary contains an element with the specified key; otherwise, false.
member.exception: key is a null reference

member.summary: Removes the value with the specified key from the ExpiringDictionary.
member.param: The key of the element to remove.
member.returns: true if the element is successfully found and removed; otherwise, false. This method returns false if key is not found in the ExpiringDictionary.
member.exception: key is a null reference

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.TryGetValue(`0,`1@)
member.summary: Gets the value associated with the specified key.
member.param: The key of the value to get.

When this method returns, contains the value associated with the specified key, if the key is found; otherwise, the default value for the type of the value parameter. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if the ExpiringDictionary contains an element with the specified key; otherwise, false.
member.exception: key is a null reference

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.SetTimer
member.summary: Update the timer to time out at the next time an element expires
member.remarks: If there are no elements in the ExpiringDictionary, then the timer is canceled

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.TimerProc(System.Object)
member.summary: Removes expired elements from the ExpiringDictionary.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.Comparer
member.summary: Gets the IEqualityComparer that is used to determine equality of keys for the ExpiringDictionary.
member.value: The IEqualityComparer generic interface implementation that is used to determine equality of keys for the current ExpiringDictionary and to provide hash values for the keys.
member.remarks: ExpiringDictionary requires an equality implementation to determine whether keys are equal. You can specify an implementation of the IEqualityComparer generic interface by using a constructor that accepts a comparer parameter; if you do not specify one, the default generic equality comparer EqualityComparer.Default is used. Getting the value of this property is an O(1) operation.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of key/value pairs contained in the ExpiringDictionary.
member.value: The number of key/value pairs contained in the ExpiringDictionary.
member.remarks: Count also includes elements that has expired but is not yet removed by the timer function. The capacity of an ExpiringDictionary is the number of elements that the ExpiringDictionary can store. The Count property is the number of elements that are actually in the ExpiringDictionary. The capacity is always greater than or equal to Count. If Count exceeds the capacity while adding elements, the capacity is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array before copying the old elements and adding the new elements. Getting the value of this property is an O(1) operation.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value associated with the specified key.
member.param: The key of the value to get or set.
member.returns: The value associated with the specified key. If the specified key is not found, a get operation throws a KeyNotFoundException, and a set operation creates a new element with the specified key.
member.exception: key is a null reference
The property is retrieved and key does not exist in the collection.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.SlidingExpiration
member.summary: The interval between the time the element was last accessed and the time at which that element expires.
member.remarks: Setting this property to TimeSpan.Zero will prevent the ExpiringDictionary from using sliding expiration.
member.value: A TimeSpan indicating how long an element can remain untouched before it is automatically removed from the ExpiringDictionary.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Util.ExpiringDictionary`2.AbsoluteExpiration
member.summary: The interval between the time the element was created and the time at which that element expires.
member.remarks: Setting this property to TimeSpan.Zero will prevent the ExpiringDictionary from using absolute expiration.
member.value: A TimeSpan indicating how long an element can remain in the ExpiringDictionary before it is automatically removed.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.Constants
member.summary: Public string constants for the Archive List system
member.remarks:
This class contains a number of subclasses, that define 'sections' of strings. Within each subclass you will find a number of string constants that are used in the Archive List system - display and restriction data types, icon hints etc.
Other constants, such as (the main) column names can be found in type archive row classes, for instance in .

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.Constants.DisplayTypes
member.summary: Display types for archive columns. The cell content (DisplayText) is always a string; however, it should be interpreted and displayed as a specific type according to the strings defined here. Numeric and date types will always be formatted with the class and need to be decoded/localized before display.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.Constants.RestrictionTypes
member.summary: Restriction types for archive columns. A column can be used as a restriction if it has one of these types; numeric and date values are expected to be either in InvariantCulture format or encoded with the .

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.Constants.IconHints
member.summary: Icon hints for archive columns. Cells that have type icon will contain one of these hints, and the GUI should translate that to the proper graphic (which will generally have the same name)

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.Constants.StyleHints
member.summary: Style hints for archive list data rows. A style hint says something about how the row should be styled, but this is indirect - thus a hint. A style hint will be something like 'processed' or 'expired'; the GUI will then translate that into some concrete behaviour, such as boldface, coloured font or whatever.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRow.AddTooltipToField(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Add a tooltip to a field in an archive row. The tooltip can be either a literal or a {} style hint. It will be added to the given column if that column either lacks a tooltip or has one of the same type. If the column is missing, nothing bad happens. The added tooltip may be null or empty, causing nothing to happen.
member.param: Name of column to add a tooltip to
tooltip to add, may be null, empty, literal or a hint

member.name: P:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRow.RowRight
member.summary: Table rights for the primary table of this row. The QueryProviderBase class by default sets this to be the TableRight of the Sentry handling the PrimaryTable of the query. Typically, buttons such as Add and Delete in archive bottom toolbars will be controlled by this right. Link hints on the separate cells may point to logic that makes changes (such as the toggle completed hint on the activity archive); such hints should be individually added/removed by the provider responsible for them based on Sentry information for that particular cell (or whatever is appropriate).

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Threading.ThreadwiseKeyCache`1
member.summary: The purpose of this class is to contain a cache of items, with a separate cache per thread. The use case is that some class needs to maintain a unique list of items, uses a cache for this, and wants the list to be kept separate for each thread - even if the instance of the cache and/or client class is the same.

member.summary: Public interface for the synchronous part of the operation. The query to be processed must be a parameter to this operation.
member.param: Query to be processed by the actual service
member.returns: TRUE if there is something to do, i.e., if AsynchronousOperation should be called

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.AsynchronousOperation
member.summary: Public interface for the asynchronous part of the operation. Any data needed for its execution has to be copied by the , because you DO NOT KNOW when the method will actually be called.
member.remarks:
You should not really call this method if the returned false, which can be checked by accessing the property. However, it is not an error to call this method anyway, as it will check the workToDo variable before actually doing anything.
However, if you forget to call , you will get an exception here.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.ScheduleNewWork
member.summary: Strategy method for starting processing of new work.
member.remarks: Derived classes must provide an implementation that somehow queues, spawns, executes or in other ways processes directly, or sets up for later processing, whatever work is in the InputQueryCopy (or the derived class' other unit of work storage).

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.ExecuteWork
member.summary: Template method that executes the actual work, by calling the abstract method.
member.remarks: ExecuteWork is called by the thread delegates provided by the various execution models. It can be overridden for special needs, but overriders should note that they MUST call , otherwise they may break the protocol.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.Processor
member.summary: Processor executing the operation.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.WasSetupCalled
member.summary: A flag property that keeps track of whether the method has been called. It is illegal to call if this flag is false.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.HasWorkToDo
member.summary: A flag property that reflects the output of . It is true if there is work to do for the .

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.AsynchronousHandler`2.ThreadName
member.summary: Thread name. The default implementation returns the query type and the table/record of the first query in the batch. Subclasses can override and add their content.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.SoSession
member.summary: Session object used to authenticate and handle a SuperOffice session
member.remarks:
NetServer is designed to be both deployed locally and server-side.
Local:
A local application is an application that does something for one user. The application starts of by authenticating the user and provides some functionality to him. On completion, the user will log out. The entire time the application provides functionality to the user, there is a valid session on behalf of this user.
Server-side:
A server-side application serves several users. Users are performing operations or requests. There is a valid session for the user while he is performing the operation and the session is suspended between operations. An example of this is a web application. The user clicks something on the browser and sends off a request to the server. While the server is processing the request, the session is valid. Between the requests, the session is suspended.
The first operation performed against NetServer in a local application will be to and the last will be to the session. The session object will not be used in extent of this in a local application.
In a server-side application, the user will be authenticated, by an underlying call to the method. As each request is completed, a should be called. As the next request starts, the suspended session will be continued using the method.
The suspend method returns a string that represents the authenticated user. This string should be stored in the web- applications session-state. As it is needed for a continuation of the session, it should be fetched back from the web-applications session-state.
The method will return a object, serialized and decrypted using . the method will use
to decrypt end deserialize the credentials.

member.summary: Container of NetServer context, managed by plug-in implementing and declared with

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.SoContextContainer.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Constructor called by de-serializer.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.SoContextContainer.System#Runtime#Serialization#ISerializable#GetObjectData(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Populates a SerializationInfo with the data needed to serialize the target object.
member.remarks:
Depending on the Data.Session. setting, we either serialize the credentials (for later reauthentication), or binary-serialize the principal itself.
The reauthentication defaults to 'false' in the config file.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.SoContextContainer.ToString
member.summary: If there is a valid inner principal, return his ToString() - generally for debug purposes. An empty string is returned if there is no valid principal (inner principal returned null).
member.returns: Current principal's ToString, or string.Empty if the inner principal is null

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.SoContextContainer.CurrentPrincipal
member.summary:
Get the CurrentPrincipal, reauthenticating it if needed If the Data.Session. setting is set to true, then the de-serialized principal is in an Unathenticated state. If this happens, an automatic authentications is triggered and the result returned; if that authentication fails then null is returned and the deserialized principal is lost.
There is also a recursion blocker, to ensure that once we decide a reauthentication is needed, recursive calls to this property do not trigger more reauthentications (for instance, from error logging)

member.exception: Thrown if the restriction does not exist, using the given text

member.summary: Scan the restriction array and return the given restriction if found; otherwise return null

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo.PatchRestrictionArray(System.Boolean,SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo[],SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo[])
member.summary: Take an array of restrictions, and patch in one or more replacements. Such replacements will be added if they are not already there, and will REPLACE any existing restrictions with the same keys. The returned array is always a copy of the original, which is not touched.
member.param: Original set of restrictions, will not be changed
Restrictions that will override existing ones with the same key
member.returns: Original restrictions, with the replacements patched in

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo.ExtractRestrictionsByBaseName(System.String,SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo[])
member.summary: Scan the restriction array and return all instances of the desired restriction. All comparisons are base name to base name, case insensitive.
member.remarks: The method performs a case-insensitive exact match search - so that looking for source/contactRestrictionId would NOT match targe/contactRestrictionId. Here, only base names are used, so there would be a match. However, it's not a simple substring search, so that source/restrictionContactId will not match contactId.
member.param: Restriction to search for, only base name will be used
Restrictions to search, only base names will be used
member.returns: Array of matching restrictions, or an empty array (never null)

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo.PrefixRestrictions(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo},System.String)
member.summary: Prefix each restriction in a collection with a certain name prefix, according to the standard prefix rules

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo.EliminateEmptyValueRestrictions(SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveRestrictionInfo[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Scan through an array of restrictions, and remove those that have a null or empty value array. Note that having a single value element that itself is null or the empty string is something different, such restrictions will be eliminated only if so requested. The return value is a copy, the original is not touched.
member.param: Array of restrictions to scan
If true, consider empty strings to be 'no value', and eliminate restrictions that have exatcly one empty string, as if they had no value at all
member.returns: Copy of input, containing only those restrictions that had non-null and non-empty value arrays

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnInfo
member.summary: This class carries information about the definition and properties of an archive display column. It is used by the archive MDO providers to construct column lists for the configuration dialogs, and by the archive control to know what type (and other properties) each column has. The class is serializable and used on both the application and Web server sides.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.CollectionOps.CreateNameValueCollection(System.String)
member.summary: Create a from a string in standard name/value format
member.remarks:
The input string should be of the format key=value&key2=value2 etc. Duplicate keys are acceptable. An empty or null input string will result in an empty (not null) return value.
The System.Web.HttpUtility.ParseQueryString method is used for the parsing, so that URL-encoded data values are handled correctly
member.param: Name/value input string
member.returns: Equivalent collection

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.CollectionOps.CreateNameValueString(System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection)
member.summary: Create a name/value string from a .
member.remarks:
Duplicate keys in the incoming collection will result in duplicate keys in the output. An empty or null input will return an empty (not null) string.
The ToString() method of the NameValueCollection class CANNOT BE used to create the string. The framework claims that Request.QueryString is a NameValueCollection, but at runtime, it's actually a System.Web.HttpValueCollection. The difference is significant because HttpValueCollection.ToString() returns the URL-encoded raw query string, but NameValueCollection.ToString() returns the default Object.ToString() result - in this case "System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection"
Thanks to http://dylanbeattie.blogspot.com/2008/12/mocking-querystring-collection-in.html for this little gem, which could otherwise do incredible damage. Fuck Microsoft for doing things like this.
We urlencode the values, since they might contain ampersands that would then scupper us later on...
member.param: Collection to be converted
member.returns: Name/value string corresponding to the collection

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.CollectionOps.ParseDelimitedStringToIntArray(System.String)
member.summary: Parse a delimited string like '1, 3,4,56, 23 15' to the int[]{1, 3, 4, 56, 23, 15}. This overload uses space, comma and semicolon as delimiters.
member.remarks: This method will split apart the input string according to the delimiters, treating multiple consecutive delimiters as one. Each substring will be parsed using int., and the result placed in the return list. If TryParse fails, no value is parsed (no exceptions thrown). An empty input will yield an empty (Length == 0) result.
member.param: Input string
member.returns: Int array of parseable values

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.CollectionOps.ParseDelimitedStringToIntArray(System.String,System.Char[])
member.summary: Parse a delimited string like '1, 3,4,56, 23 15' to the int[]{1, 3, 4, 56, 23, 15}
member.remarks: This method will split apart the input string according to the delimiters, treating multiple consecutive delimiters as one. Each substring will be parsed using int., and the result placed in the return list. If TryParse fails, no value is parsed (no exceptions thrown). An empty input will yield an empty (Length == 0) result.
member.param: Input string
Array of delimiter characters; multiple consecutive delimiters will count as one
member.returns: Int array of parseable values

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Factory.TypeFactories
member.summary: Object representing the different kind of Factories for a given Type.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Factory.TypeFactories.Create(System.Type,System.Type[],System.Object[])
member.summary: Create an instance of an object compatible with the type.
member.param: The type of object that should be created.
Array of argument types that the constructor supports. For further reference, see the method.
Array of arguments that corresponds to the constructorArgumentTypes. For further reference, see the method.
member.returns: Instance of an object representing the type.
member.remarks:
The Create method tries to locate a type to create using the following order:
with high priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to High.
with high priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to High. There also needs to be a presence of the Factory in the configuration.
Custom type through configuration
A custom type from the configuration is used, given that there is a constructor supporting the argument types provided.
with normal priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to Normal. There also needs to be a presence of the Factory in the configuration.
with normal priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to Normal.
with low priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to Low. There also needs to be a presence of the Factory in the configuration.
with low priority
The implementation must be marked with the and implement the interface . The property must be set to Low.
Using Type directly
The type is used, given that there is a constructor supporting the argument types provided.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Util.XmlUtil
member.summary: This class contains utility methods for manipulating Xml elements

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.XmlUtil.Merge(System.Xml.XmlNode,System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Merge two XML trees
member.remarks:
Equivalent nodes appear only once in the output. Two element nodes are treated equivalent if: their local names are equal, their namespace-uris are equal, and all their attributes are equal. Two text nodes are treated equal if their normalized content is equal. The same rule applies for comments and processing instructions.
See http://www.informatik.hu-berlin.de/~obecker/XSLT/ for a more detailed explanation!
member.param: First XML tree
Second XML tree
member.returns: Markup of result

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.XmlUtil.InnerMerge(System.Xml.XmlNode,System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Merge the inner XML's of two XML trees, i.e., leave the outer element alone (it is assumed to match), and merge the inner parts.
member.remarks: See the other Merge method for information on the merge process
member.param: First XML tree
Second XML tree
member.returns: Markup of result, which does NOT contain the outer parts of any of the input elements

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper
member.summary: Utility class for WindowsIdentity

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonUser(System.String,System.String,System.String,SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType,SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider)
member.summary: The LogonUser function attempts to log a user on to the local computer, that is, to the computer from which LogonUser was called. You cannot use LogonUser to log on to a remote computer. You specify the user with a user name and domain, and authenticate the user with a clear-text password. If the function succeeds, you receive a WindowsIdentity that represents the logged-on user.
member.param: This is the name of the user account to log on to. If you use the UPN format, user@DNS_domain_name, the domain parameter must be null.
If this parameter is NULL, the user name must be specified in UPN format. If this parameter is ".", the function validates the account using only the local account database.
Clear-text password for the user account specified by userName.
Specifies the type of logon operation to perform.
Specifies the logon provider.
member.returns: WindowsIdentity representing the logged on user
member.remarks: For further reference, se the platform SDK (e.g. Advapi32.lib and advapi32.dll) for method LogonUser.
member.exception: Thrown if the user fails to log on.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.TryLogonUser(System.String,System.String,System.String,SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType,SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider)
member.summary: Attempt to log on to the local computer. Same functionality as , but does not throw exceptions on failure (null return)
member.param: This is the name of the user account to log on to. If you use the UPN format, user@DNS_domain_name, the domain parameter must be null.
If this parameter is NULL, the user name must be specified in UPN format. If this parameter is ".", the function validates the account using only the local account database.
Clear-text password for the user account specified by userName.
Specifies the type of logon operation to perform.
Specifies the logon provider.
member.returns: WindowsIdentity representing the logged on user; or null if the logon failed for any reason

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.GetErrorMessage
member.summary: Get an error message through the underlying Platform SDK.
member.returns: Error message as returned from the operating system.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType
member.summary: Logon type used with LogonUser.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.Interactive
member.summary: This logon type is intended for users who will be interactively using the machine, such as a user being logged on by a terminal server, remote shell, or similar process. This logon type has the additional expense of caching logon information for disconnected operation, and is therefore inappropriate for some client/server applications, such as a mail server.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.Network
member.summary: This logon type is intended for high performance servers to authenticate clear text passwords. LogonUser does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.Batch
member.summary: This logon type is intended for batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention; or for higher performance servers that process many clear-text authentication attempts at a time, such as mail or web servers. LogonUser does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.Service
member.summary: Indicates a service-type logon. The account provided must have the service privilege enabled.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.Unlock
member.summary: This logon type is intended for GINA DLLs logging on users who will be interactively using the machine. This logon type allows a unique audit record to be generated that shows when the workstation was unlocked.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.NetworkCleartext
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: This logon type preserves the name and password in the authentication packages, allowing the server to make connections to other network servers while impersonating the client. This allows a server to accept clear text credentials from a client, call LogonUser, verify that the user can access the system across the network, and still communicate with other servers.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonType.NewCredentials
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: This logon type allows the caller to clone its current token and specify new credentials for outbound connections. The new logon session has the same local identify, but uses different credentials for other network connections. This logon type is supported only by the LOGON32_PROVIDER_WINNT50 logon provider.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider
member.summary: Logon provider used with LogonUser

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider.Default
member.summary: Use the standard logon provider for the system. The default security provider is NTLM. Windows XP: The default provider is negotiate, unless you pass NULL for the domain name and the user name is not in UPN format. In this case the default provider is NTLM.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider.WinNT35
member.summary: Use the Windows NT 3.5 logon provider.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider.WinNT40
member.summary: Use the NTLM logon provider.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Util.WindowsIdentityHelper.LogonProvider.WinNT50
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Use the negotiate logon provider.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState
member.summary: Authentication state of the current
member.remarks:
The initial state of is allways Unauthenticated. When the authentication starts, the state is set to Authenticating. The state is set to Authenticated if the authentication succeeded and AuthenticationFailed if the authentication failed.
The authentication state is set to Disconnected or Closed if such operations are performed on .
A value greater than Unauthenticated means that the process of authentication is either being carried out or has actually been successfull. is available when the athentication are in these states.
A value less than Unauthenticated means that we don't have a valid session.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.Unauthenticated
member.summary: The process of authentication has not been carried out.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.Authenticating
member.summary: The session is currently being authenticating

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.Authenticated
member.summary: The session is authenticated

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.AuthenticationFailed
member.summary: The authentication has failed.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.Suspended
member.summary: The session has been suspended.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthenticationState.Closed
member.summary: The session has closed

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState
member.summary: Authorization state of the current . This replaces Authentication state of which now is made obsolete.
member.remarks:
The initial state of is allways Unauthorized. When the Authorization starts, the state is set to Authorizing. The state is set to Authorized if the Authorization succeeded and AuthorizationFailed if the Authorization failed.
The Authorization state is set to Disconnected or Closed if such operations are performed on .
A value greater than Unauthorized means that the process of Authorization is either being carried out or has actually been successfull. is available when the Authorization are in these states.
A value less than Unauthorized means that we don't have a valid session.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.Unauthorized
member.summary: The process of Authorization has not been carried out.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.Authorizing
member.summary: The session is currently being Authorizing

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.Authorized
member.summary: The session is Authorized

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.AuthorizationFailed
member.summary: The Authorization has failed.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.Suspended
member.summary: The session has been suspended.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.AuthorizationState.Closed
member.summary: The session has closed

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Threading.GlobalQueuedThreadBase`2
member.summary:
This class provides a queue implementation for the queued asynchronous execution strategy, that gives us one single queue for the whole NetServer instance. See remarks for important information on execution context!
*** NOTE *** on Context: The AsyncContext that is associated with the executing thread is based on the context of the thread that started it. Since this is not predictable, and may change (if the queue empties), you CANNOT ASSUME that the execution context for any unit of work is that of the calling (client) thread!
Therefore, this execution model should only be used if the context is not relevant - that may not be so often.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2
member.summary: This class is a base class for execution strategies that queue asynchronous work.
member.remarks: This class provides a queued execution strategy. However, it does not provide a concrete implementation of the queue itself, since there are several ways to skin that particular cat.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor, only called from derived classes.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.ScheduleNewWork
member.summary: Scheduling strategy method, provides the basic "queue and process in FIFO order" strategy
member.remarks:
The queue actually used is an abstract property, that must be implemented by a derived class. This ducks the question of what kind of queue we're using, whether it is static by the calling thread, or whatever.
If no worker thread is currently running, one is created after the work has been queued.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.ThreadDelegate(SuperOffice.Threading.AsyncContext,SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase{`0,`1}.WorkInfo)
member.summary: Thread delegate that actually performs queued work.
member.remarks: The next unit of work is pulled from the queue. A BatchSave for the result is created, passed to the dervied class' method, and the result is executed through the method. When the queue is empty, the thread is allowed to expire.
member.param: Context information from the ThreadManager

Unit of work storage, which contains the queue. It is passed as a parameter because it might be ThreadStatic, making direct access impossible (this delegate is run in the worker thread, not the caller thread in which the queue is declared).

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.WorkInformation
member.summary: The derived class must provide an implementation of actual storage/allocation of units of work, in whatever manner supports the execution model.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.ThreadCounter
member.summary: The derived class must provide an actual performance counter to track when worker threads are spawned and killed.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Threading.QueuedThreadBase`2.WorkInfo
member.summary: Unit of work information, contains a work queue and a thread present flag

member.summary: Queue of work, actually instances of our derived classes

member.summary: Flag to keep track of the presence of a worker thread. Set/reset outside of queue operations to ensure there will be no orphaned work

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Exceptions.PerformanceMonitoring
member.summary: This class is an encapsulation of the Windows Performance Counters. Use the static Increment/Decrement methods combined with the Counters enum to do your counting. All public methods are thread safe.
member.remarks:
Performance counter categories cannot be edited, i.e., you cannot add a new counter to an already existing category. At the same time, enumerating all counters to see if they match the current definitions in the code takes a loooong time, there is some kind of timeout or hangup in there.
Therefore, you must set the CreateCounters property to true in the Diagnostics section of the config file, and run once to re-create all categories, if you run for the first time or have changed/added to the counter definitions.
To add a new counter, you need to do several things: 1) Add a new member to the enum. 2) Add corresponding cases or switches (if new category) to the , to bind the enum to a category and counter name. Finally, you must add counter creation data to the or other creation method (make a new one for a new category); this is where you set up the counter name, help and type information that is needed by the system and shown in Perfmon.

Incoming counter name
member.returns: Counters enum corresponding to input data, or Unknown

member.summary: Obtain the object associate with a category name and counter name. Note that it only works for "our" counters, not the system categories and their members.

Counter name
member.returns: Counter object
member.exception: If you pass in an unknown/misspelled category and counter name, you will get an exception, not a null reference. This is because referring to a misspelled counter is probably something you want to discover!

member.summary: The visible display value for an archive cell. It is always a string, and other data types are converted to string according to the invariant culture. Further conversion to the local culture is the responsibility of the client.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData.TooltipHint
member.summary: The tooltip hint is either a text to be shown (after resource tag substitution), or a tooltip key to be given to the tooltip provider system in order to asynchronoously retrieve the actual tooltip.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData.LinkHint
member.summary: The link hint consists of information to construct an actual link; additional information (such as a view context) must be provided by the client, who is also responsible for building the link. The content of the link will generally be one or more ids, such as contact_id=123.

member.name: P:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData.OrderByValue
member.summary: This property contains an object to be used for order comparisons. It may be the same as the display value, but it may also be different, as with fields that are built up from separate components but are ordered ny one of the components (or the Japanese case, where Kanji name fields are ordered according to their Kana equivalents)

member.name: P:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData.RawValue
member.summary: This property contains the 'raw' value. A raw value is a strongly typed object that represents the raw data used to derive the display value. For instance, a list column will have the list item name in the display value, and the ID in the raw value; numeric columns will have an Int32 or Double raw value, datetime columns will have a DateTime, and columns that represent enumerations or statuses - where the display value is typically an icon hint - will have the raw numeric value.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Util.TwoWayDictionary`2
member.summary: This class implements a two-way associate container, that is, a dictionary-like collection that is indexable both by the left and right-hand values. This places key-like constraints on both sides (they must be comparable, hasheable, and unique), but provides fast lookup in both directions.
member.remarks: The implementation internally uses two generic dictionaries, so that all constraints, performance characteristics and other properties of the generic class apply. LeftType and RightType can be the same type, which incidentally requires things like the TryGetValue methods to have different names for left and right...

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.TwoWayDictionary`2.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor, allocates empty dictionaries. Insertions will take O(n) where n is the number of items already in the container; note that if you're populating in a loop that would give a total performance of O(n^2), worth avoiding by preallocating if at all possible.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.TwoWayDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor that preallocates the given number of slots. Insertions will take O(1) up to this initial capacity, O(n^2) beyond.
member.param: Initial capacity to allocate, this reserves memory but is not a hard limit

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.TwoWayDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`0})
member.summary: Constructor that preallocates the given number of items, and uses the given comparer for the left-hand key type. Insertions will take O(1) up to this initial capacity, O(n^2) beyond.
member.param: Initial capacity to allocate, this reserves memory but is not a hard limit
Equality comparer for the given key type

member.name: M:SuperOffice.Util.TwoWayDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`0},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`1})
member.summary: Constructor that preallocates the given number of items, and uses the given comparers for the left-hand and right-hand key types. Insertions will take O(1) up to this initial capacity, O(n^2) beyond.
member.param: Initial capacity to allocate, this reserves memory but is not a hard limit
Equality comparer for the left-hand key type
Equality comparer for the right-hand key type

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions
member.summary: Functions

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.Section
member.summary: Section heading

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.ThreeStateStatusCheckbox
member.summary:
Enables three completion statuses for follow-ups: Not started, Started and Completed. (Default = NO)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.AcademicTitle
member.summary:
Use academic title for persons. (Default = NO)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.BackgroundDocumentCheckTimer
member.summary:
Documents on the Activities section tab can be checked in the background. The availability of a specified document plug-in and of each individual document is checked. Here you enter the number of seconds between each document check. Default: 1.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.BlankApptClick
member.summary:
Specifies the type of activity to create when you double-click on a blank line in the Activities section tab in the Company or Project screens.
Control type: List, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.CapitalFirstLetterCompanyName
member.summary:
Should the first letter in every word in the company name automatically be converted to a capital letter? (Default = YES)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.CapitalFirstLetterPersonName
member.summary:
Should the first letter in every word in the contact name automatically be converted to a capital letter? (Default = YES)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.DisableContactDogEar
member.summary:
Removes the corner tabs on the Company card if there are too many companies - i.e. more than this number
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.DisableDelKey
member.summary:
If YES, the user has to use the menu in order to delete a company, project or selection (Default = YES).
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.DisplayDateFormatInLists
member.summary:
Specifies the date format used in section tabs in CRM (ex. dd.mm.yyyy hh:mm). (Default: computer's regional settings for short date format.)
Control type: Text, access: Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.EditIfVisible
member.summary:
Allows other users to add and remove members from any selection visible to the user
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.EnableBackgroundDocumentCheck
member.summary:
Documents on the Activities section tab can be checked in the background. The availability of a specified document plug-in and of each individual document is checked. This may happen at the cost of server capacity. Alternatively, documents are checked when the user enables the right-click menu. It will then take longer for a document to open, since it first has to be checked. The default is ON.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.FilterBookingSlaves
member.summary:
Filter out invitations for everyone except the person making the invitation, to avoid duplicates in the list.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.ForceConfirmation
member.summary:
Always displays confirmation dialog when deleting
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.GetAdvanceDays
member.summary:
Number of days ahead to display tasks in the checklist. Default is 21 days
Control type: Number, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.GetRecordCounts
member.summary:
Whether to display record counts in lists. This takes slightly longer but provides a useful overview.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.HomeContact
member.summary:
Which contact is displayed when you click on Hugo (the owl in the Navigator)
Control type: ContactId, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.InternetUseIntegratedBrowser
member.summary:
Uses the internal CRM browser when clicking a URL within CRM. Default is Yes. If you set this preference to No, your computer's default browser will be used instead.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.PastDateAlert
member.summary:
Marks overdue activities in section tabs (Default = YES)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.PeriodicCheckInterval
member.summary:
How often (in minutes) should CRM check the database for new invitations etc.
Control type: Number, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.RemoveInvitationDuplicates
member.summary:
This ensures that invitations are displayed only once in the Activities section tab in CRM (Default = YES).

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Functions.UseCaseOnTemplateVariables
member.summary:
The template variables used in, for instance, documents and addresses are output in lower case and get the text exactly as stored in the database by default. Setting this preference will change the text to uppercase for all or just the first letter, depending how the template variable is input. (Default: No).

Use this character to delimit e-mail addresses. (Default: ';').

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveAppointments
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving appointments you send from SuperOffice CRM by e-mail. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all appointments sent by e-mail from CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveDocuments
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving documents you send from SuperOffice CRM by e-mail. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all documents sent by e-mail from CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveForwards
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving e-mail forwarded from SuperOffice CRM. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all e-mail you forward from CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveReplies
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving replies to e-mails that are archived in SuperOffice CRM. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all e-mail you reply to from CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveSentMsg
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving e-mail created in SuperOffice CRM. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all e-mail you create in CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.ArchiveToAssocs
member.summary:
Always proposes archiving e-mail written internally to your associates using SuperOffice CRM. This means that, by default, you will be asked if you want to archive all e-mail sent to associates from CRM.web.
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SaveLogonInfo
member.summary:
Saves an encrypted version of your user name and password for the e-mail server in the CRM database. This saves you having to enter your user name and password each time you want to access your inbox. (Default = NO)
Control type: Bool, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SendFaxPrefix
member.summary:
Format for fax numbers to be sent by e-mail. <faxs> is the fax number and <name> is the company name, e.g. FAX:<name>@<faxs> produces FAX:SuperOffice ASA@22517001
Control type: Text, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SendFaxProtocol
member.summary:
Protocol used by your e-mail server to send a fax. (Default = FAX)
Control type: Text, access: Admin, Crm, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SmtpServerName

Control type: Text, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SmtpServerPass

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SmtpServerPort

Control type: Number, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.Mail.SmtpServerUser
member.summary:
If you want to use a different user name from the one you use to log in to your IMAP server, you can enter it here.
Control type: Text, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

Number of seconds that CRM.web will wait for the mail server to finish processing a request. If you experience problems with slow response times from your mail server, you should increase this value to 30 seconds or more. Default: 15 seconds.
Control type: Number, access: Admin, Admin users, Wizard

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.SentryAddonNames
member.summary: Sentry Addons: [SentryAddonNames] dummy-name = prog.id. The prog.id is requred and matches ProgId property of the sentry plugin attribute.
member.remarks: Verification is done by adding a progid string to the sentry plugin attribute, so that NetServer plugins can declare the COM progid without having to actually be COM compatible. NetServer can then check the sentry preferences and verify that all progids are present before allowing user to log in. Ignore Sentry in config file or logging in with system user disables the sentry plugin check.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.SentryAddonNames.Section
member.summary: Section heading

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.DocPluginNames
member.summary: Doc Plugin Addons: [DocPluginNames] plugin-id = prog.id. The prog.id is requred and matches COM ProgId property of the document plugin class.
member.remarks:
NetServer document plugins declare the plugin-id without having to actually be COM compatible.
Another list of plugin names (Human names, not COM progid names) is found in the PrefDescLine section, used by the user-preference GUI to let the user select a program.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.DocPluginNames.Section
member.summary: Section heading

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.DocTemplateTypeMap
member.summary:
DocTemplate Type Mapping: [DocTemplateTypeMap] .xyz = .docx
Maps a template's unknown file type to a know file type before tag-substitution logic is run on the template
member.remarks: This is an extension point to allow unknown doc template types to use the existing doc template handling. It does not allow adding new types of template handling. It is purely an alias mapping.

member.name: F:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.DocTemplateTypeMap.Section
member.summary: Section heading

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.UserPreferenceStrings.RequiredDynamicLoad
member.summary: Required dynamic load: Add new preference section for NetServer only [RequiredDynamicLoad] name = regexp
member.remarks: This mechanism is more general than [SentryAddonNames] - it applies to all dynamic loaded assemblies in NetServer. Missing any one these required assemblies will cause NetServer to fail. The regexp is used to match against the loaded assemblies full names (including version and strongname). This allows a preference to match more than one possible name. Using the full name allows a preference to match a strong name, so that it is harder to fake out with a dummy replacement assembly.

member.name: T:SuperOffice.Security.Principal.UsernamePasswordWindowsTokenSupplier
member.summary: This class is responsible for trying to map UserNameSecurityToken to windows users.
member.remarks: It is not used as a token supplier (see , since the attempt to log on to Windows can take a significant amount of time. Instead, the class is called from the see class; that one is run fairly late in the authentication process, and at a point where other options have already been tried.

member.param: Currently knowns security tokens
member.returns: True if at least one Windows identity was authenticated and added

member.name: T:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1
member.summary:
Comparer class used to compare two ArchiveRow objects according to the given orderby criteria. This class handles comparisons by both OrderByValue and DisplayValue, type harmonization and conversions, and multiple ascending/descending orderby criteria.
If you have a set of archive row iterators, you can use the class to sort the iterators according to their .Current rows

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1.#ctor(SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveOrderByInfo[])
member.summary: Construct the comparer, and set the orderby criteria.
member.param: Set of ordering criteria. null is not acceptable. An empty array will cause all elements to be considered equal to another; the final result then depends on the behaviour of the sorting algorithm. If the algorithm is 'stable', no change in order will happen; otherwise the final ordering is undefined.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1.CheckAndSetOrderByValue(SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData)
member.summary: Check the OrderBy property of the archive column data, and set it if it is null. We first let try parsing, and accept its result if it is non-string. If that fails, we try to parse date, int and double in that order to get correct sorting comparisons. null value is allowed for the parameter, nothing happens then.
member.param: Archive Column data whose OrderBy is to be checked and possibly set

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1.HarmonizeOrderByValues(SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData,SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData)
member.summary: Check the types of the OrderBy values of the given columns, and harmonize them if needed. Harmonization reverts both to string if they are not of the same type. null values are allowed; nothing happens.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1.ColumnComparer(SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData,SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.ArchiveColumnData)
member.summary: This is a comparison method that can be passed as a comparer to the various Sort methods in the .NET framework. It compares the incoming Archive Rows according to the orderBy values (displayValues if orderByValues are null), in the order and direction specified by the current orderby settings.
member.param: left hand iterator, whose current row is used
right hand iterator, whose current row is used
member.returns: -1, 0 or 1 according to the ordering criteria

member.name: M:SuperOffice.CRM.ArchiveLists.TypedArchiveRowComparer`1.Compare(`0,`0)
member.summary: Compare two ArchiveRow elements according to the orderby criteria set
member.param: Left-hand row
Right-hand row
member.returns: -1, 0 or 1 according to actual row data order

member.name: T:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter
member.summary:
A SerializationWriter instance is used to store values and objects in a byte array.
Once an instance is created, use the various methods to store the required data. ToArray() will return a byte[] containing all of the data required for deserialization. This can be stored in the SerializationInfo parameter in an ISerializable.GetObjectData() method.
As an alternative to ToArray(), if you want to apply some post-processing to the serialized bytes, such as compression, call AppendTokenTables first to ensure that the string and object token tables are appended to the stream, and then cast BaseStream to MemoryStream. You can then access the MemoryStream's internal buffer as follows:
writer.AppendTokenTables(); MemoryStream stream = (MemoryStream) writer.BaseStream; serializedData = MiniLZO.Compress(stream.GetBuffer(), (int) stream.Length);

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.Write(System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Writes an ArrayList into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte upwards depending on data content Notes: A null Arraylist takes 1 byte. An empty ArrayList takes 2 bytes. The contents are stored using WriteOptimized(ArrayList) which should be used if the ArrayList is guaranteed never to be null.

member.param: The BitArray value to store.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.Write(SuperOffice.IO.IOwnedDataSerializable,System.Object)
member.summary: Allows any object implementing IOwnedDataSerializable to serialize itself into this SerializationWriter. A context may also be used to give the object an indication of what data to store. As an example, using a BitVector32 gives a list of flags and the object can conditionally store data depending on those flags.
member.param: The IOwnedDataSerializable object to ask for owned data
An arbtritrary object but BitVector32 recommended

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteObject(System.Object)
member.summary:
Stores an object into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte upwards depending on type and/or content.
1 byte: null, DBNull.Value, Boolean
1 to 2 bytes: Int16, UInt16, Byte, SByte, Char,
1 to 4 bytes: Int32, UInt32, Single, BitVector32
1 to 8 bytes: DateTime, TimeSpan, Double, Int64, UInt64
1 or 16 bytes: Guid
1 plus content: string, object[], byte[], char[], BitArray, Type, ArrayList
Any other object be stored using a .Net Binary formatter but this should only be allowed as a last resort: Since this is effectively a different serialization session, there is a possibility of the same shared object being serialized twice or, if the object has a reference directly or indirectly back to the parent object, there is a risk of looping which will throw an exception.
The type of object is checked with the most common types being checked first. Each 'section' can be reordered to provide optimum speed but the check for null should always be first and the default serialization always last.
Once the type is identified, a SerializedType byte is stored in the stream followed by the data for the object (certain types/values may not require storage of data as the SerializedType may imply the value).
For certain objects, if the value is within a certain range then optimized storage may be used. If the value doesn't meet the required optimization criteria then the value is stored directly. The checks for optimization may be disabled by setting the OptimizeForSize property to false in which case the value is stored directly. This could result in a slightly larger stream but there will be a speed increate to compensate.
member.param: The object to store.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Calls WriteOptimized(string). This override to hide base BinaryWriter.Write(string).
member.param: The string to store.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.Write(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Writes a TimeSpan value into the stream. Stored Size: 8 bytes
member.param: The TimeSpan value to store.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.Write(System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stores a Type object into the stream. Stored Size: Depends on the length of the Type's name and whether the fullyQualified parameter is set. A null Type takes 1 byte.
member.param: The Type to store.
true to store the AssemblyQualifiedName or false to store the FullName.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Writes an non-null ArrayList into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte upwards depending on data content Notes: An empty ArrayList takes 1 byte.
member.param: The ArrayList to store. Must not be null.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Collections.BitArray)
member.summary: Writes a BitArray into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte upwards depending on data content Notes: An empty BitArray takes 1 byte.
member.param: The BitArray value to store. Must not be null.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Collections.Specialized.BitVector32)
member.summary:
Writes a BitVector32 into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 to 4 bytes. (.Net is 4 bytes) 1 to 7 bits takes 1 byte 8 to 14 bits takes 2 bytes 15 to 21 bits takes 3 bytes 22 to 28 bits takes 4 bytes ------------------------------------------------------------------- 29 to 32 bits takes 5 bytes - use Write(BitVector32) method instead
Try to order the BitVector32 masks so that the highest bits are least-likely to be set.
member.param: The BitVector32 to store. Must not use more than 28 bits.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Writes a DateTime value into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 3 bytes to 7 bytes (.Net is 8 bytes) Notes: A DateTime containing only a date takes 3 bytes (except a .NET 2.0 Date with a specified DateTimeKind which will take a minimum of 5 bytes - no further optimization for this situation felt necessary since it is unlikely that a DateTimeKind would be specified without hh:mm also) Date plus hh:mm takes 5 bytes. Date plus hh:mm:ss takes 6 bytes. Date plus hh:mm:ss.fff takes 7 bytes.
member.param: The DateTime value to store. Must not contain sub-millisecond data.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Writes a Decimal value into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte to 14 bytes (.Net is 16 bytes) Restrictions: None
member.param: The Decimal value to store

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Int16)
member.summary: Write an Int16 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.remarks:
0x0000 - 0x007f (0 to 127) takes 1 byte 0x0080 - 0x03FF (128 to 16,383) takes 2 bytes ---------------------------------------------------------------- 0x0400 - 0x7FFF (16,384 to 32,767) takes 3 bytes All negative numbers take 3 bytes
Only call this method if the value is known to be between 0 and 16,383 otherwise use Write(Int16 value)
member.param: The Int16 to store. Must be between 0 and 16,383 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Int32)
member.summary: Write an Int32 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.remarks:
0x00000000 - 0x0000007f (0 to 127) takes 1 byte 0x00000080 - 0x000003FF (128 to 16,383) takes 2 bytes 0x00000400 - 0x001FFFFF (16,384 to 2,097,151) takes 3 bytes 0x00200000 - 0x0FFFFFFF (2,097,152 to 268,435,455) takes 4 bytes ---------------------------------------------------------------- 0x10000000 - 0x07FFFFFF (268,435,456 and above) takes 5 bytes All negative numbers take 5 bytes
Only call this method if the value is known to be between 0 and 268,435,455 otherwise use Write(Int32 value)
member.param: The Int32 to store. Must be between 0 and 268,435,455 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Int64)
member.summary: Write an Int64 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.param: The Int64 to store. Must be between 0 and 72,057,594,037,927,935 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.String)
member.summary:
Writes a string value into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 1 byte upwards depending on string length Notes: Encodes null, Empty, 'Y', 'N', ' ' values as a single byte Any other single char string is stored as two bytes All other strings are stored in a string token list:
The TypeCode representing the current string token list is written first (1 byte), followed by the string token itself (1-4 bytes)
When the current string list has reached 128 values then a new string list is generated and that is used for generating future string tokens. This continues until the maximum number (128) of string lists is in use, after which the string lists are used in a round-robin fashion. By doing this, more lists are created with fewer items which allows a smaller token size to be used for more strings.
The first 16,384 strings will use a 1 byte token. The next 2,097,152 strings will use a 2 byte token. (This should suffice for most uses!) The next 268,435,456 strings will use a 3 byte token. (My, that is a lot!!) The next 34,359,738,368 strings will use a 4 byte token. (only shown for completeness!!!)
member.param: The string to store.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Writes a TimeSpan value into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. Stored Size: 2 bytes to 8 bytes (.Net is 8 bytes) Notes: hh:mm (time) are always stored together and take 2 bytes. If seconds are present then 3 bytes unless (time) is not present in which case 2 bytes since the seconds are stored in the minutes position. If milliseconds are present then 4 bytes. In addition, if days are present they will add 1 to 4 bytes to the above.
member.param: The TimeSpan value to store. Must not contain sub-millisecond data.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Type)
member.summary: Stores a non-null Type object into the stream. Stored Size: Depends on the length of the Type's name. If the type is a System type (mscorlib) then it is stored without assembly name information, otherwise the Type's AssemblyQualifiedName is used.
member.param: The Type to store. Must not be null.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Write a UInt16 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.remarks:
0x0000 - 0x007f (0 to 127) takes 1 byte 0x0080 - 0x03FF (128 to 16,383) takes 2 bytes ---------------------------------------------------------------- 0x0400 - 0xFFFF (16,384 to 65,536) takes 3 bytes
Only call this method if the value is known to be between 0 and 16,383 otherwise use Write(UInt16 value)
member.param: The UInt16 to store. Must be between 0 and 16,383 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Write a UInt32 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.remarks:
0x00000000 - 0x0000007f (0 to 127) takes 1 byte 0x00000080 - 0x000003FF (128 to 16,383) takes 2 bytes 0x00000400 - 0x001FFFFF (16,384 to 2,097,151) takes 3 bytes 0x00200000 - 0x0FFFFFFF (2,097,152 to 268,435,455) takes 4 bytes ---------------------------------------------------------------- 0x10000000 - 0xFFFFFFFF (268,435,456 and above) takes 5 bytes
Only call this method if the value is known to be between 0 and 268,435,455 otherwise use Write(UInt32 value)
member.param: The UInt32 to store. Must be between 0 and 268,435,455 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Write a UInt64 value using the fewest number of bytes possible.
member.param: The UInt64 to store. Must be between 0 and 72,057,594,037,927,935 inclusive.

member.name: M:SuperOffice.IO.SerializationWriter.WriteOptimized(System.Object[],System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes a pair of object[] arrays into the stream using the fewest number of bytes possible. The arrays must not be null and must have the same length The first array's values are written optimized The second array's values are compared against the first and, where identical, will be stored using a single byte. Useful for storing entity data where there is a before-change and after-change set of value pairs and, typically, only a few of the values will have changed.
member.param: The first object[] value which must not be null and must have the same length as values2
The second object[] value which must not be null and must have the same length as values1
